transcription.text: [ Music ]
>> So this talk is basically designed to come
after my first talk which hopefully, I mean,
there are more of you listening to that talk
in this talk so I guess we won't have a big problem.
And basically the first talk was kind of discussing the problem space,
what are the kind of design requirements that we have
when we are trying to build a public consensus protocol.
And CASPER is my kind of and you know,
in collaboration with Vitalik and a few people,
solution, attempted solution to this public consensus problem.
So this talk should give you kind of an overview of the process
that led to the development of CASPER,
CASPER's design philosophy, the different parts of CASPER as a protocol
and then the failure modes like you know, what can go wrong
given how many faulty nodes.
So let's get started.
So the first design principle is that it should be suited
for public consensus which is basically to say suited
for the kind of analysis that I shared in my talk earlier this morning.
Basically CASPER should work in a context
where a majority of nodes are rational and colluding
to undermine protocol.
And then a rational, a role include
in large majorities in order to undermine protocol guarantees
so as long as that's profitable.
So basically what we want to have is coverage
of Byzantine faults with disincentives.
And specifically, busy default to that undermine protocol guarantees.
So and the reason we want to cover them with disincentives
is because we want an attacker who has a budget to spend
to have to budget a lot of money in order
to undermine the properties of the consensus protocol.
So this is like the first most important design goal of CASPER.
We want to make it expensive for an adversary
to bribe a rational majority of nodes
to undermine the protocol.
So we want to cover this space of Byzantine faults
with disincentives.
That's important, but not involved.
So another key design goal is that it should be like client friendly.
And then the last design goal is that it should be good
for users and application developers.
And there's two main ways that I--
what that means to me, one of them
is that CASPER tells you the state of the finality of transactions.
So you won't be surprised if a transaction is reverted,
and you will know when it can't be reverted.
And then CASPER is also a little latency,
which I think is really important for user experience.
I mean, as everyone probably agrees,
when you're at a website, you want it to respond right away.
And distributed application should be the same way.
So and we're going to cover based
some background knowledge before we really get into the heart
of what's new about CASPER.
So first thing is security.
CASPER is a variation on security deposit-based proof
stake.
So it's hard to stress enough how important security deposits
are to secure in public because it's a protocol,
especially for stake because it's protocols.
And then I'll explain why.
First, I'll mention that this concept was discovered independently
by many people, including J.Kwan, Nick Williamson of credits.
J.Kwan is working on this project called Tenderment,
Dominic Williams, who we saw on a panel earlier in Vitalik
and I. We all thought of this idea
that we could use security deposits to secure a consensus
protocol.
And the idea is that people would have to place a security
deposit in order to produce blocks.
And if they do something bad, then they would lose their deposit.
So proof stake in general uses digital assets
that define in the consensus as an anti-sibyl mechanism.
Whereas proof of work uses computational resources
defined outside of the consensus as an anti-sibyl mechanism.
And there are other variations on this kind of proof of work
thing, a theme of using outside resources,
like you have proof of stores, proof of bandwidth,
and all these things could be used conceivably
as anti-sibyl mechanism.
And there have been some people who look
at designs of cryptocurrencies based on those.
But basically, there's traditionally
said to be two fundamental problems of first stake,
that nothing is a stake problem and the long-range tag problem.
So the thing that's a stake problem basically
is an interitional proof stake protocol
is like pure coin, et cetera.
Next, nodes don't have any disincentive from being Byzantine.
Signatures are easy to produce, and they
don't lose tokens for being Byzantine.
And so they have an incentive to sign on both chains.
And they basically have no expenses.
And so any profit they can make from underlying
undermining the consensus protocols guarantees
is something that they will do in a worst-case analysis
because they don't have any disincentives.
And they'll basically do it for free.
Security deposits solve anything at stake problem
by requiring that validate us put something at stake.
And by removing that security deposit,
when they're demonstrably Byzantine in some way.
So it basically requires that this proof of them being
Byzantine is discovered and published to the blockchain
in order to affect their balances and their deposits.
Because everything that affects the state of the blockchain
has to be published into the blockchain
and so that the state transition function can update
the state of their bonds or the state of something
in the ledger.
So basically, as long as these evidence transactions aren't
censored, faults can be punished.
And now this is kind of a broad, almost philosophical point
where improved work, the consensus--
In producing changes, the consensus is always expensive
in an effort to make it prohibitively expensive
for an attacker to produce a longer, more heavier fork.
So it's more expensive always for the network
than an attacker should be willing to spend at any time.
In security deposit proof stake,
consensus should be cheap for everyone,
except for attackers during an attack.
And this is kind of a big shift in approach
where instead of everyone always incurring more of an expense
than an attacker might ever incur, people don't incur an expense,
but an attacker will incur a very large expense.
So this approach promises to be much more economically
efficient because instead of everyone
having to always incur an expense,
only attackers occur at the expense during an attack.
So this is also very--
This is like an important perspective change
in how to secure consensus.
So improved work, the disincentive is basically, again,
the disincentive is not receiving an incentive
for which compensates you for your computational work.
In security deposit proof stake,
the disincentive is basically just a little forfeiture
of their security deposit.
So then we have a long-range attack problem.
Long-range attack problem is basically
that an adversary controls old keys, keys that no longer
have coins in them, perhaps.
And well, the reason we assume they don't have keys in them
is because it's cheap for the attacker to buy these keys.
The attacker could use old keys to produce chains
that have a higher score.
And this is kind of fundamental and traditional proof of stake.
And it's fundamentally all proof of stake,
so long as the thing that people use to authenticate
the current state is the genesis block.
Because the genesis block is something
that our current assumption produced a long time ago.
And the people who have something at stake then
no longer have something at stake now.
And so if you rely on their signatures,
their signatures effectively mean nothing.
Because they no longer have something at stake
and it can't be punished for equivocating,
for making bad signatures.
So what we need to do to get around long-range attack problem
is to change the authentication model.
Instead of authenticating everything
based on your knowledge of the genesis block,
you authenticate based on your knowledge
of who currently has something at stake
and therefore who currently has signatures that you can trust.
So basically, this means that clients
have to know who currently has a deposit
in order to synchronize to the state.
And if they're able to stay online often enough,
then they'll be able to maintain this list.
So the validators rotate over time.
The set of validators today is not
going to be the same as the set of validators in two years.
So if you come online in two years with only knowing
the list of the validators today,
you're not going to be able to synchronize the consensus.
But if you come online regularly enough
to watch the validators rotate, then you
can use the fact that you know who's bonded today
to learn who's bonded in the future at every step
using the economic assurance that if these people were
lying to you, they would lose their security deposits.
So this kind of is a thing called weak subjectivity.
And basically, it's kind of like a single public key
for the whole blockchain, which you
need to authenticate out of band before you can synchronize,
and which kind of changes over time.
But you can watch the change happening
if you have the current public key.
So you can kind of be man in the middle attack
if you have the wrong key there.
And you'll show up in some kind of non-existent economy.
And so there's basically some trade-offs here.
In proof of work, you just need to know the Genesis block
and you can authenticate the current state.
Whereas in this kind of proof-stake model,
you need to be online sufficiently often
to have a current picture of the set of bonded validators.
So there is some cost there in terms
of what we can provide as a service to nodes who
are offline very often.
But there is one main benefit to this approach,
which is that it's much, much, much more
like client-friendly than proof work
or any Genesis block authentication model could ever be.
Because you don't have to download header change.
You don't have to compare scores of forks that
come from the beginning of time.
You just have a piece of currently economically
meaningful information, which you can use to immediately sync
up with the current state.
And so the level of client-friendliness
that's possible in this kind of weekly subjective model
is much, much greater than what's
possible in proof of work or kind of Genesis block
authentication model.
So those are the trade-offs for that design.
Again, this idea of that you need to know
that people currently have deposits,
it's fundamental to using security deposit base
for staying in a way that is economically secure.
Because people who no longer have deposits
are willing to sell their keys for free, almost free,
for epsilon and epsilon is great in the zero.
So some more background knowledge
is the ghost protocol for proof of work.
This is a protocol called greedy, heaviest observed
subtree produced by some Bolinsky and Zohar quite some time
ago.
And basically, it can reduce the block latency
without reducing the security for a proof of work chain.
In proof of work, a minor is only rewarded for a block
if it is eventually part of the chain.
So these things called orphan blocks, which a minor finds,
but doesn't get included in the chain.
And these blocks don't contribute to security of Bitcoin,
for example.
But in Ethereum, we have this kind of implementation of ghosts
that makes it so that we include orphan blocks
and they contribute both to the score of the fork
and we compensate the miners for the work.
So the miners aren't screwed by having their block
be orphaned, and thus the fork is secured
because we don't lose the work.
The work still is part of the comparison of the forks.
So basically, ghost made proof of work lower latency
without compromising on security.
So and basically, but there are--
in Ethereum, we have an implementation of ghosts,
but it's not the full ghost protocol
as given by Zohar and Sam Polanski.
And basically, we include the headers of orphan blocks
into block chains and that will contribute to their fork.
But what we don't do is actually have a block tree-based rule.
And the reason we do this is because it's simpler
and we get most of the benefits.
But if we did have the full implementation,
we could have even lower latency blocks,
so we'd be able to execute transactions for orphan blocks.
And self is mining and mining pools
would be even less attractive.
So CASPER is an adaptation of ghosts to proof-stake.
And we have this similar kind of thing
where we can have a more complex version with trees
or a simpler version that still has some of the ghost-like
properties.
And this is one of the things that we're
still debating between me and TALIC
about what would be appropriate for the release of CASPER.
Basically, so certainly incentives
will be a function of orphaned information.
So that much we agree on.
Now, what we don't agree on is whether or not
we will allow orphan blocks to have the bets that they're
including contribute to that history or whether to execute
transactions for market blocks.
If we allow these things, then we will have--
it'll be a little bit more complex
in the protocol point of view, but we'll
be able to have slightly lower latency.
And basically, with more complex versions of CASPER
that fully implement this tree choice rule,
we can go well below the end-to-end network latency
in terms of producing blocks, which
is good for user experience, but it increases
the implementation complexity because we actually
have to do tree choice as opposed to just block chain
choice.
So if all blocks are obtained in a single chain,
then you have to wait for at least half a network latency set.
Well, you will have to wait for the next validator
to produce a block on the previous one's block.
So we kind of argue about whether the complexity of bringing
the block time below the network latency is worth it.
Additionally, this is kind of a neat thing.
I came up with a way to make this tree choice rule
light client friendly.
So you could imagine that as a light client watching
like sub network latency blocks, you
might have a kind of a nightmare.
Really?
I'm going through this left?
You're kidding.
Oh my god.
Do I actually have to do this?
Oh my god.
OK, so you calculate the tree choice rule
in the state transition function,
and you can trust it to see if there's a function.
So we might have a map of the cap theorem
from our previous talk.
CASPER chooses availability.
We're going to do consensus by having iterative
betting on whether blocks win at a particular height.
And basically, the betting games at different heights
are independent, and the betting games can finalize blocks.
If you have a whole bunch of finalized blocks in a row,
then you have a finalized state.
So non-finalized blocks-- sorry, finalized blocks
aren't reverted for kind of two reasons.
One of them is that reverting a finalized block
would create a very large amount of evidence of malfeasance,
which would lead to a very large amount of loss
of security deposits.
So we have an economic assurance that two finalized blocks
won't be created because it creates a lot of this evidence,
which can be used to punish a lot of them, which means that
in adversary, we have to spend a lot of money
to revert a finalized block.
And the other reason is that clients with their for choice
rule will refuse to adopt a fork that
doesn't include a finalized block.
And so this version of finality via clients
strict unwillingness to revert blocks
can lead to consensus failure in the case
where there's two finalized blocks shown
to two different clients before they
see each other's finalized blocks.
But it provides an ironclad guarantee of finality
in the sense that we know that this block will not
be reverted because the client just refuses
to do it based on their for choice rule.
So the CASP are designed to be sensitive resistant.
Basically, the way we do this is we--
if some nodes are offline, we're going to disincentivize--
if we're going to see that they were censored
and punish everyone.
So if you were to censor some majority,
then the remaining everyone would lose money.
So that if a large coalition were to cooperate to censor
a minority, then they would have to do that at their expense.
So unlike proofwork and traditional proof-stake,
you don't get a raise for censoring.
You lose money.
Your salary goes down.
So-- and now we basically have to go through our failure
modes really quickly.
So history reversion is something
that can happen for non-finalized blocks.
In which case, clients will know that the block wasn't finalized
because CASP tells you the state of the finality of the block.
And so there is some significant mitigation there.
Preventing finality is kind of a more serious failure
mode where a coalition could stop finality from occurring,
which prevents them from introducing
a new set of validators.
This is kind of important.
You need to finalize a new set of validators
before the first set of validators can rotate
because you must know for sure who the validators are
when you come online as a client.
Censorship is another-- is like the most severe failure mode.
If censorship is successful, then evidence transactions
can't get in and people aren't going
to be disincentivized from committing
disentine behavior because they won't
lose their security deposits.
So while we do have an economic assurance
that their censorship is expensive,
if you get sufficiently close to 100% of nodes
to get together to censor, that disincentiv's shrinks
because the protocol can't tell if there's any censorship,
if all nodes are censoring.
If some nodes are missing, it could
know it could kind of infer that maybe the blocks in those nodes
aren't being included.
So moreover, the cost of censorship only
exists for a finite amount of time
because we can't punish people forever if some nodes are offline.
So there is a cost that an adversary can pay to censor
the network.
And then there are some ways to mitigate it.
One of them is through cryptographic means,
through time lock cryptography, and sorry, I'm really close to done.
Or on just getting transactions basically
to make it hard to censor some transactions
without censoring all of them.
There's also economic sanctions.
Clients can detect censorship under certain network
assumptions.
And then they could treat that fork as having a low score.
And therefore choose another fork, which
might have a minority of nodes who aren't censoring.
Or we could just create a hard fork
that removes the censoring validators from the set of validators.
And if there's enough community backing behind it,
then that's a very strong economic disincentive to attack
if the community is able really to govern the code so well
that they can hard fork in response to censorship.
So while some of these failing modes are pretty bad,
actually, CASR has more complete coverage
of faults in this kind of economic setting
than any other consensus protocol out there right now.
But the devil is in the details.
There's lots of parts of these, the way
that these rules for incentivizing consensus
and incentivizing things have to be specified.
So the complete specification isn't available yet,
as you may have noticed.
And there's still details of the protocol
that you can finalize.
However, we are starting to do formal implementation
and verification of protocol.
Specifically, we're looking at it like some of the economics
of mostly the convergence properties.
And that concludes my talk.
Sorry for the rest.
